meta.name: description
meta.content: A new virus that began in December 2019 has spread to the United States. In late February, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Americans should prepare for COVID-19.
A new virus that began in December 2019 has spread to the United States. In late February, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Americans should prepare for COVID-19.

div.div: Not finding a county service? Browse our full list of services
Not finding a department? Browse our full list of departments
View agendas and watch theBoard meetings.

p.a: The interim guidance we're providing is based on what is currently known about COVID-19. Multnomah County will update this interim guidance as additional information becomes available.

div.p: ASL |አማርኛ | العربية | Burmese | Español | 中文 | 繁體中文 | Chuukese | فارسی | Français | 日本語 | Kajin Majōl | Kishwahili | ကညီကျိ | 한국어 | Kosrean | नेपाली | Palauan | Pohnpeian | русский | Soomaali | ภาษาไทย | กริญญา | Tiếng Việt | Tongan

img.alt: drawing of a woman in a house
img.title: stay home to save lives

h2.img: Stay Home, Except for Essential Needs

div.p: On March 23, Governor Kate Brown issued an order directing everyone in Oregon to stay at home unless absolutely necessary. The order is effective immediately, and remains in effect until ended by the governor.

ul.li: Go out only for essentials (groceries, medical care)
Stay at least 6 feet from others any time you are out
Gatherings of members of the same residential household are allowed

li.a: List of what's allowed and what's not»

div.p: Multnomah County Sheriff’s Office FAQs on enforcement of Governor’s Order (PDF)

Call the law enforcement non-emergency number, 503-823-3333, if you are concerned about people gathering. Includes Portland Police and Multnomah County Sheriff (for all cities and unincorporated areas in Multnomah County).
The virus that causes COVID-19 passes easily from person to person. To stay healthy:

ul.li: Stay at least 6 feet from others
Prevent the spread of germs by washing hands often and covering your cough

p.a: More tips from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Face coverings, medical masks and what you should know»

img.title: if you start to feel sick

h2.img: What to do if you are sick

div.p: If you start to feel sick—especially with a fever and cough—stay home and do the things you normally do to feel better. Sleep, rest, and drink plenty of fluids. There is no specific medicine for COVID-19.

ul.li: Steps to take if you are sick or think you may be infected with coronavirus
Check your risk for COVID-19 to help you decide if you should seek medical care.
If you need to seek care, call your doctor before going to the clinic. They will tell you what to do next.

div.p: This video is available in many languages. Please help us share this information widely in our multicultural and multilingual communities. Get translated versions»

hr.p: The way we do business, care for each other and interact in our community is changing while we work to slow the spread of the virus.

li.a: Centers for Disease Control & Prevention FAQs

hr.p: Call 2-1-1 7 days a week, 8 a.m. to 11 p.m., for basic COVID-19 questions, or to find social and health services.

img.alt: Disease detective Anne Schwindt take a rare pause from her COVID-19 work to pet Hyacinth the therapy dog.
img.title: Disease detective Anne Schwindt take a rare pause from her COVID-19 work to pet Hyacinth the therapy dog.

figcaption.span: A little help from our (furry) friends

img.alt: Chair Deborah Kafoury announces a temporary eviction moratorium in Multnomah County on March 17
img.title: Chair Deborah Kafoury announces a temporary eviction moratorium in Multnomah County on March 17

figcaption.span: Board votes to align COVID-19 eviction moratorium with state’s
The Multnomah County Board of Commissioners voted unanimously Thursday, April 16, to clarify the County’s COVID-19 eviction moratorium while also continuing to protect residential tenants.

img.title: Community health workers learn about COVID-19 to educate others

div.p: Community support is community health. Spread facts. Not fear.

img.alt: Multnomah Building closed to the public temporarily to slow spread of COVID-19
img.title: Multnomah Building closed to the public temporarily to slow spread of COVID-19

h2.a: What’s closed — and what is open — at MultCo during COVID-19 outbreak

div.p: Libraries, passport office and some student health centers are closed.
The dashboard details cases over time and break down cases by age group, sex at birth. Viewers can explore test results, hospitalization rates, and common symptoms.
